div.p: Birth is one of the 16 major BIOGRAPHY elements defined as integral to mapping a woman's life. It captures information concerning the date, place, birth position and context of a person's birth where known. Birthdates should be entered in CHRONSTRUCT form where available, for extraction from individual biography documents to be placed within other general chronologies. This mandatory element is usually the second Div1 content element in a BIOGRAPHY section (after PERSONNAME). It will almost always include a chronstruct for date of birth, and has one sub-element, BIRTHPOSITION, for capturing position in family (attributes Eldest, Youngest, Only), or more general description

Birth should be entered as a chronology event with the form HB was born in London, but also with some detail if possible to make a more interesting statement. Please use a full sentence with the verb in past tense. Whenever possible a place should be given for a woman writer's birth, to facilitate mapping of locations.

Only one place tag should be included inside birth elements; it is assumed that the place tagged within birth is the location of the woman writer's birth and will be mapped accordingly. If you want to record a place of baptism, do it in attached SHORTPROSE. Should contain a CHRONSTRUCT if there is solid information; if birthdate is a mystery Birth should contain a SHORTPROSE including a tagged date with attribute indicating uncertainty. Identify place of birth if possible, describe and tag position in family where known; do not tag parentsâ€™ names here.
Question: What happens if the birth date is unknown?

Answer: Since birth is a required element, include a sentence conveying the information that birth date is unknown or uncertain or contested. In these instances, it is suggested that the researcher include a research note detailing the sources they have checked trying to locate a date so that research will not be duplicated.
